Line 37: Line 37:
While Google did not expect that hobbyists would use and evaluate Chromium OS ahead of its official release, [[Sundar Pichai]], Google vice president of product management, said that "what people like Hexxeh are doing is amazing to see." Pichai said the early releases were an unintended consequence of open source development. "If you decide to do open-source projects, you have to be open all the way."<ref name="NYT:Hexxeh"/>
While Google did not expect that hobbyists would use and evaluate Chromium OS ahead of its official release, [[Sundar Pichai]], Google vice president of product management, said that "what people like Hexxeh are doing is amazing to see." Pichai said the early releases were an unintended consequence of open source development. "If you decide to do open-source projects, you have to be open all the way."<ref name="NYT:Hexxeh"/>
â
Hexxeh's work continued into the following year. He announced "Chromium OS Lime" in December 2010,<ref>{{cite web|last=Hexxeh|title=Now with a citrus twist|url=http://hexxeh.net/?p=328117639|work=Hexxeh's Blog|accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> and in January 2011, released "Luigi", an application designed to "[[Privilege escalation|jailbreak]]" the [[Google]] [[Cr-48]] "Mario" prototype hardware and install a generic [[BIOS]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Hexxeh|title=Your princess is in another castleâ¦|url=http://hexxeh.net/?p=328117655|work=Hexxeh's Blog|accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> The developer made the builds available in virtual machine format on March 13, 2011, the date of his most recent blog posting.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hexxeh|title=In my VirtualBox?|url=http://hexxeh.net/?p=328117684|work=Hexxeh's Blog|accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> With no official build of Chromium OS forthcoming from Google, Hexxeh's "Vanilla" nightly builds of Chromium OS remain the principal resource for people wanting to try Chromium OS.
+
Hexxeh's work continued into the following year. He announced "Chromium OS Lime" in December 2010,<ref>{{cite web|last=Hexxeh|title=Now with a citrus twist|url=http://hexxeh.net/?p=328117639|work=Hexxeh's Blog|accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> and in January 2011, released "Luigi", an application designed to "[[Privilege escalation|jailbreak]]"/"[[Rooting (Android OS)|root]]" the [[Google]] [[Cr-48]] "Mario" prototype hardware and install a generic [[BIOS]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Hexxeh|title=Your princess is in another castleâ¦|url=http://hexxeh.net/?p=328117655|work=Hexxeh's Blog|accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> The developer made the builds available in virtual machine format on March 13, 2011, the date of his most recent blog posting.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hexxeh|title=In my VirtualBox?|url=http://hexxeh.net/?p=328117684|work=Hexxeh's Blog|accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> With no official build of Chromium OS forthcoming from Google, Hexxeh's "Vanilla" nightly builds of Chromium OS remain the principal resource for people wanting to try Chromium OS.
In May 2011, [[Dell Computer]] also released a new build for Dell Inspiron Mini 10v netbook, following up on an earlier build released almost 18 months earlier. The build did not support audio, but was bootable from a USB drive.<ref>{{cite news|last=Linder|first=Brad|title=Dell releases Chromium OS build for Inspiron Mini netbooks|url=http://liliputing.com/2011/05/dell-releases-chromium-os-build-for-inspiron-mini-netbooks.html|accessdate=16 May 2011|newspaper=Liliputing|date=May 15, 2011}}</ref>
In May 2011, [[Dell Computer]] also released a new build for Dell Inspiron Mini 10v netbook, following up on an earlier build released almost 18 months earlier. The build did not support audio, but was bootable from a USB drive.<ref>{{cite news|last=Linder|first=Brad|title=Dell releases Chromium OS build for Inspiron Mini netbooks|url=http://liliputing.com/2011/05/dell-releases-chromium-os-build-for-inspiron-mini-netbooks.html|accessdate=16 May 2011|newspaper=Liliputing|date=May 15, 2011}}</ref>
